p: The manuscript is in the mail, except for "Laurel Decade" which I still have to do some work on. I will send or bring it later. The rest is all there, and I recommend that you read it straight through just as if you never heard of John G. Neihardt (as if anyone hasn't!) and it's all new. Then go over it again to make comments. When you see it all at once you get a different effect from reading isolated chapters. Quite a bit of it is new, more about your work.
I should caution you that the footnotes are not accurate. I didn't want to delay getting it to you till I could get all
all the corrections in and I can't send my one revised copy. I included them so you could get an idea of what kind of details I've put in footnotes to keep them from interruping the flow.

I will arrive on Saturday the 7th of June, and as soon as I get in I'll call you. We should have some time on Saturday unless the plane is awfully late - it gets in fairly early in the afternoon. I will have to have on the 10th, but not till afternoon, and will have three good days.

One of my English department colleagues has been reading the chapters- she knows criticism, and she teaches modern poetry. You'll be interested in her reaction. SHe wants to read the whole Cycle straight through, and she says
your work is impressive and you sound like a great win if you have never written anything. I think myself the Song of the Poet is the best of all - and that doesn't run down the epics either.

It will be very good to see you - it sure like a long time. I have been with you so much in my mind that I can hardly believe it is two years since we've talked face to face. We have a lot to catch up on.
I'm trying to write this in big handwriting. It's wonderful that your eyes can be better - won't they go on improving as you recover form the surgery?
Bower sends love. He is very busy all the time, and we don't play often- we almost have to make appointments to see each other. He is reading the

manuscript, too - he says it's about his favorite poet. I will store up all his comments for you, and I may quote Stewart too. He sends love, by the way. Stewart still considers that he has a special position with you as honorary grandson. I'm enclosing a copy of his announcement- he's getting married in September.
I hope you like the book!
More later- I have an appointment with a lot of footnotes.
